comments.body: These were copied from scipy. I'm not sure what the platform_system stuff is for.
Not sure if it matters but we technically required `3.5.3` as a minimum

Do we have any idea if pandas builds at all on AIX ?

> Not sure if it matters but we technically required 3.5.3 as a minimum

This line does not control the python version, it is only saying that if you have python 3.5, you need that numpy. 

But that said, I am wondering if there is a way to specify python_requires as well in the pyproject.toml world.
I suspect not, since this is invoked by pip, and pip is tied to a particular python?
@ayappanec do you happen to know if pandas can be built / used with AIX? We're trying to determine if these workarounds you added to SciPy's pyproject.toml are needed in ours as well.

But that pip with a specific python still needs to know if it can build/install pandas or not (depending on the python version). Currently this information is in setup.py, but I thought pyproject.toml would allow (if not using setuptools, but eg flit) having no setup.py. 

Anyway, that's not an important issue for this PR ;)

Numpy 1.16.0 ( and from that level onwards ) has a patch that is required for building projects like Scipy (which depends on numpy's script for gfortran flags) in AIX . So if Pandas also has the same approach , then we need to have these same conditions.
Thanks. Pandas has NumPy as a build dependency, but we don't do anything with fortran. So it sounds like we're safe to remove the AIX things?
Okay. But still i feel like having these conditions doesn't do any harm i guess. So better we will have those on the safer side.
Since we are targeting 1.0 now I guess can remove the line for 3.5 support

> Since we are targeting 1.0 now I guess can remove the line for 3.5 support

Master still has 3.5 support I think?
Yeah, I don't know that we've discussed dropping python 3.5 for 1.0. I think the idea was to follow the NEP policy if that gets done in time (I think it's supposed to be merged this week?)
yeah, thought we should prob remove for 3.5

> Yeah, I don't know that we've discussed dropping python 3.5 for 1.0. I think the idea was to follow the NEP policy if that gets done in time (I think it's supposed to be merged this week?)

https://github.com/pandas-dev/pandas/issues/27492#issuecomment-513545165

diffHunk:
@@ -1,1 +6,10 @@    "wheel",
    "Cython>=0.29.13",  # Note: sync with setup.py
    "numpy==1.13.3; python_version=='3.5' and platform_system!='AIX'",
    "numpy==1.13.3; python_version=='3.6' and platform_system!='AIX'",
    "numpy==1.14.5; python_version>='3.7' and platform_system!='AIX'",

comments.body: Looking over the `black` issue tracker it looks like we should be specifying all versions instead of just the lower bound.  The logic being that a new version of Python could change the syntax such that a kind of formatting that `black` thinks is ideal is no longer supported.
is there a reason for pyproject.toml instead of setup.cfg?
`black` does not support configuration through `setup.cfg` nor do they plan on supporting it in the future

Shouldn't that be "numpy>=1.15.4"? I had issues installing pandas from source with numpy 1.18.5 installed.
Should I create a ticket for that?

I don't believe so. We build with the oldest supported NumPy that is compatible with the version of NumPy.

> I had issues installing pandas from source with numpy 1.18.5 installed.

This also doesn't quite make sense. The idea behind pyproject.toml is to isolate the build environment. It shouldn't matter what version of NumPy was used to build pandas with, as long as it's binary compatible (IIUC).

Ok, ignore my comment if that is how you make sure that your build with the oldest supported version.

In my case I have numpy 1.18.5 installed and I want to use it to build pandas from source. However, it complains that the build requirements are note met. 
```
Installing build dependencies ... error
ERROR: Complete output from command /opt/project/venv37/bin/python3.7 /opt/project/venv37/lib/python3.7/site-packages/pip install --ignore-installed --no-user --prefix /tmp/pip-build-env-0xz070yu/overlay --no-warn-script-location --no-binary :none: --only-binary :none: --no-index --find-links https://project:omniscale@pkgs.omniscale.net:443/project -- setuptools wheel 'Cython>=0.29.13' 'numpy==1.13.3; python_version=='"'"'3.6'"'"' and platform_system!='"'"'AIX'"'"'' 'numpy==1.14.5; python_version>='"'"'3.7'"'"' and platform_system!='"'"'AIX'"'"'' 'numpy==1.16.0; python_version=='"'"'3.6'"'"' and platform_system=='"'"'AIX'"'"'' 'numpy==1.16.0; python_version>='"'"'3.7'"'"' and platform_system=='"'"'AIX'"'"'':
ERROR: Ignoring numpy: markers 'python_version == "3.6" and platform_system != "AIX"' don't match your environment
Ignoring numpy: markers 'python_version == "3.6" and platform_system == "AIX"' don't match your environment
Ignoring numpy: markers 'python_version >= "3.7" and platform_system == "AIX"' don't match your environment
Looking in links: https://*redacted*
Collecting setuptools
Collecting wheel
Collecting Cython>=0.29.13
Collecting numpy==1.14.5
  ERROR: Could not find a version that satisfies the requirement numpy==1.14.5 (from versions: 1.18.5)
ERROR: No matching distribution found for numpy==1.14.5
```
However, were you using python 3.8? There was an issue with us not having a line for py38. https://github.com/pandas-dev/pandas/pull/34667
Ok, I think I didn't quite understood how build isolation works. Thanks for your quick relies!
